DOCUMENT:
The nearly 6,000 pilots at Delta Air Lines, proving resistant to a second round of concessions, voted overwhelmingly to approve a strike should their contract be voided by an arbitration panel, the pilots' union said yesterday. The panel is expected to issue a ruling by April 15. The decision by the pilots gives negotiators on both sides more than a week to narrow their differences and avoid a work stoppage that many believe would lead to a liquidation of Delta. Among the issues is the company's request for $305 million in annual pay cuts; the pilots have offered $140 million. '' The Delta pilots will strike if their contract is rejected,'' said Lee Moak, a pilot and chairman of the Delta chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association. Delta filed for bankruptcy protection in September, and after the filing both sides agreed to arbitration rather than have a bankruptcy judge rule on management's motion to void the pilots' contract and impose lower wages and other conditions. Under the agreement between the pilots and the airline, which covers 1.4 million workers, they would receive new, higher salaries next year, while some work years would be shortened. But the $315-a-month salary offered by the union - an amount rejected by the company - was not enough to satisfy pilots, who voted by 61 percent to 39 percent to authorize a strike as early as Monday if their demands were not met. A similar vote would also give the National Mediation Board the authority to compel the airline to negotiate under binding arbitration, as the pilots' unions demanded in negotiations. The new deal could face strong opposition from politicians in Congress.
  choice: The panel is expected to issue a ruling by April 15.
  choice: Among the issues is the company's request for $305 million in annual pay cuts; the pilots have offered $140 million. ''
  choice: The decision by the pilots gives negotiators on both sides more than a week to narrow their differences and avoid a work stoppage that many believe would lead to a liquidation of Delta.
  choice: A similar vote would also give the National Mediation Board the authority to compel the airline to negotiate under binding arbitration, as the pilots' unions demanded in negotiations.
  choice: The new deal could face strong opposition from politicians in Congress.
  choice: But the $315-a-month salary offered by the union - an amount rejected by the company - was not enough to satisfy pilots, who voted by 61 percent to 39 percent to authorize a strike as early as Monday if their demands were not met.
  choice: Under the agreement between the pilots and the airline, which covers 1.4 million workers, they would receive new, higher salaries next year, while some work years would be shortened.
  choice: The Delta pilots will strike if their contract is rejected,'' said Lee Moak, a pilot and chairman of the Delta chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association.
  choice: Delta filed for bankruptcy protection in September, and after the filing both sides agreed to arbitration rather than have a bankruptcy judge rule on management's motion to void the pilots' contract and impose lower wages and other conditions.
  choice: The nearly 6,000 pilots at Delta Air Lines, proving resistant to a second round of concessions, voted overwhelmingly to approve a strike should their contract be voided by an arbitration panel, the pilots' union said yesterday.

targets: As if it were a gift from God, with an empty smile on his face he asks me to let him know that you're doing fine so we could be friends again someday soon!
multiple_choice_targets: It's been a strange life; constantly setting back to what I guess could be called checkpoints.
I didn't quite understand what was going on when I was younger, but now I have gotten use to second, and even third chances.
Everytime I die, I get sent back to the decision that caused my untimely demise so I may try to avoid the ultimate consequence.
In high school I was the king.
I was an outcast who had no friends, and had to hide behind a mask of indifference.
But in college I became a star.
And then, at twenty-two years old, I decided to change everything.
I went from being the king to the outcast.
I changed my name to "The King" because it sounded cooler than the other options.
I started wearing my hair down.

targets: A tear ran down his cheek and he wiped it away.
multiple_choice_targets: Unless yesterday's still unresolved elections result in Republican control of both houses of Congress, the 2002 midterm elections won't matter much in Washington.
In every other scenario, the branches of government will remain divided and gridlock will continue.
The real importance of this election is not at the national level -- it's at the state level.
Republicans have held the majority of governorships since 1995.
But yesterday Democrats cut into that majority, heading toward victory even in big-state Republican strongholds like Michigan, Illinois and Pennsylvania.
Democrats are also expected to win more than half of all seats in the U.S. House of Representatives.
That means they'll be able to pass legislation with a simple majority rather than the 60 votes needed for most bills now.
And if they can get enough Democratic support on key issues such as health care reform or tax cuts, then they could make significant gains in the Senate.
If so, the next president could be able to shape policy without having to rely on the filibuster.
But the biggest impact of today's results may come from the way voters react to them.

I've seen world's that'll shock your eyelids.
But this one?
This was just…different.
It had something about it that was almost magical.
Something about it was so alien, yet familiar at the same time.

Men and women, engineers and bureaucrats all sat around the large central table, their suits and uniforms betraying their mental states through their dishevelled nature. None dared to speak out of turn; to interject without very careful forethought in this ominous hour. This evening had been a long one for us – we'd just finished working on our last big project at BHP Billiton's Devon factory when it became apparent that an event like mine would not be able make up for some small number of short-term delays during construction which have left hundreds stranded with little hope or money after years spent repairing other companies' factories'. I USED to be a lawyer. As in, I was the general counsel for a law firm that represented members of Congress. And my clients were Senate and House members from all across America. I helped run those lawyers through elections. And it just never occurred to me that they would do anything other than the exact thing their political bosses wanted them to do: win elections. The first step in accomplishing this feat is convincing an entire legislative body (the legislature) to reelect you or your candidate. This takes hard work, because every time we elect someone to office we create another set of potential losers to contend with. You need people like Howard Berman who are both smart enough not to go out and say "It's not really about me anymore." The good news is: Most incumbents who fail get a second chance in three years or less if they have friends or family on both sides of the aisle.

Why did they keep coming back to remind him?
Jack took a deep breath and tried to concentrate on the water he was standing waist deep in.
It numbed his body and that he was grateful for.
If only it would numb his mind.
He heard the familiar sound of footsteps approaching from behind.
He turned around and saw three girls wearing their school uniforms.
They were all about Jack's age, but the girl closest to Jack was clearly older than them.

Most writers have to pay (with time or money) to get feedback other than "It was nice," so anyone serious would likely welcome it. Of course, they're not all serious here, so, yeah, I'd ask first. For example, whenever I post a prompt, I leave a blanket offer for feedback or criticism about anything posted in that prompt, but I always ask first before giving it. Most want it, some some don't. If you're really set on doing it, go after people writing longer pieces. They almost certainly want more constructive feedback, because they're usually building up to writing a novel or something. As with everything else, it's best to be polite and courteous and show them your respect when it's offered, but if someone doesn't respond, don't let it bother you too much. You may decide later why you didn't do it, or maybe you just don't like the author. But again: it will take time for those reviews to happen; you might even wind up having fewer or less helpful comments in general, but what can you do? 5.

DOCUMENT:
In the backyard of my childhood, there was a stream that served many purposes. It would clean the water as it flowed in and out from the source; it provided an artificial pool for our little group of children to swim; it provided protection against predators like raccoons and coyotes, which were common at this time of year; and when I became quite a young adult, it allowed me and my family to bathe comfortably without fear of running into the street to reach the bathroom door. However, over time, my parents began to notice some negative effects from using the water that surrounded us: The rocks around the stream started to be coated with brown, sticky substances. We had to regularly rinse our hands thoroughly before eating, or we'd accidentally ingest enough wet sand to turn black and lose any and all color from our skin. My younger brother developed acute gastroenteritis, and soon thereafter, his mother noticed he couldn't stop vomiting after eating. And on a more frequent basis, we found ourselves rushing down the street, terrified of stepping into the water because of the silt. Eventually, I and my friends learned that what these people saw as "fun" had become a dangerous practice – one that could potentially harm everyone who went swimming in their yards. So how did a game like this get turned into something so harmful? Well, this type of activity is called river-dwelling and began gaining popularity through folkloric practices back in the 1700s. At first, it consisted of individuals fishing for fish from ponds that ran alongside rivers, but then in the 1800s, authorities began to regulate this practice by prohibiting those who lived within 1 mile of a river from entering them to take part in such activities.

multiple_choice_targets:
HOW TO MAKE: My Mothers Classic Thick Roll
Ingredients:
1 dashi-maki tamago (rolled thick omelet), 6 inches by 2 inches by 1 inch
16 medium-thick asparagus spears
16 medium shrimp in their shells (31 to 35 count per pound)
Sea salt
Sugar
Komezu (rice vinegar)
1 cup sanaka no oboro (sweet fish flakes)
6 simmered shiitake mushrooms (3 ounces)
16 strips 8-inch-long simmered kanpyo gourd
6 cups (lightly packed)* prepared sushi rice (1 1/2 cups, 9.5 ounces, per roll)
4 whole sheets nori (laver); choose the thick variety.
Cut the omelet in half lengthwise.
Cut each half of the omelet in half again lengthwise, then cut each quarter piece in half again lengthwise.
You will have eight even-sized logs.
Add the asparagus and cook for 3 minutes on each side or until just tender.
Remove from pan and set aside.
Drain the cooked asparagus and chop it coarsely.
Add the chopped asparagus to the pan with the shrimp.
Cook over medium-high heat until the asparagus is lightly browned.
Transfer to a plate lined with paper towels.
